introduction.p: Our goal in this activity set is to figure out how to convert from describing vectors in terms of one basis to describing vectors in terms of another basis.

prelude.p: First, let's remind ourselves of the concept of coordinate vector.

introduction.p: Suppose V is a three-dimensional vector space, and \basisfont{B} = \{ \uvec{u}_1, \uvec{u}_2, \uvec{u}_3 \} is a basis for V.

task.p: If \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \left[\begin{smallmatrix} 9 \\ -2 \\ 4 \end{smallmatrix}\right] , then \uvec{v} = \uvec{u}_1 + \uvec{u}_2 + \uvec{u}_3 .

postlude.p:
The matrix in
that allows us to convert from coordinate vectors relative to one basis to coordinate vectors relative to another basis is called the transition matrix from basis \basisfont{B} to \basisfont{B}', and is denoted \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}.
